column1: Duarte is located on historic U.S. Route 66 which today follows Huntington Drive through the middle of the city. The town holds an annual Salute to Route 66 Parade on the third weekend in September on Huntington Drive.
Duarte is located at 34°08′25″N 117°57′42″W.According to the United States Census Bureau

column2: Duarte is in California's  32nd congressional district

The current mayor is Tzeitel Paras-Caracci.The Los Angeles County Department of Health Services operates the Monrovia Health Center in Monrovia

column2: a band of Shoshonean-speaking Indians established settlements in what is now the San Gabriel Valley. These Native Americans came to be called the Gabrieliño Indians (after San Gabriel
column3: the local mission) by early Spanish explorers
column4: but now prefer to be called the Tongva. The Tongva did not practice agriculture
column5: but instead relied upon the wild seeds
column7: and plants that grew near the rivers and marshlands. Since the San Gabriel Valley area was home to large numbers of oak trees such as coast live oak and interior live oak
column8: a staple of the Tongva diet was an acorn mush made by boiling acorn flour.

column1: Duarte's history with Europeans dates back to 1769
column2: when all land in California was claimed by the king of Spain. The first Europeans visited the San Gabriel Valley
column4: during a 1769 expedition from San Diego to Monterey Bay commanded by Don Gaspar de Portolà. Accompanying Portolà was a Franciscan priest from Junípero Serra's order in Mexico
column6: who served as the diarist of the expedition. Much of what is known of early California is known only from the detailed descriptions recorded by Crespi.

column3: the Franciscans established the Mission San Gabriel Arcangel in the San Gabriel Valley. The mission was a resting point for early California travelers and gathered most of the native Tongva into an agricultural lifestyle. Following Mexican independence in 1821
column4: the mission lands were nationalized.
Juan Bautista Alvarado
column5: granted to former Mexican corporal Andrés Duarte and his wife nearly 7
column6: 000 acres (28 km2) of prime land in the central-northern San Gabriel Valley. Duarte named his new holdings "Rancho Azusa de Duarte". The name Azusa was derived from Asuksa-gna
column7: the name of the Tongva settlement on the Foothills of California
column8: on the western side of the alluvial fan where the San Gabriel River exits the San Gabriel Mountains; a portion of this area forms the northeasternmost corner of Duarte.  That land grant now comprises portions of Arcadia
column13: portions of Azusa and a portion of Baldwin Park.  Corporal Duarte had the local Indians build a small hut for his family and help him plant a kitchen garden and orchards near "the Indian Springs of the Asuksas" (in what is now Fish Canyon).

column1: Alta California was given to the United States in 1848 following the end of the Mexican–American War. In 1851
column2: Congress passed a bill that established a Board of Land Commissioners whose duty was to determine the validity of all grants of Alta California land by Spanish and Mexican authorities.

column1: Corporal Duarte began incurring legal expenses and other debts
column2: which he defrayed by selling portions of his Rancho. This first sale was a 225-acre (0.91 km2) parcel at the southern end of the Rancho to Michael Whistler and two unidentified colleagues. Whistler later bought out his colleagues and sold the entire parcel to Dr. Nehemiah Beardslee
column3: who started the first school in Duarte (which now bears his surname) and laid out the first section of Duarte's water lines. Corporal Duarte divided much of the Rancho's remainder into 40-acre (16 ha) plots and sold them individually.  Corporal Duarte finally won a favorable ruling from the Supreme Court for his land grant case in 1878
column4: but by then he had sold the entire Rancho.

column1: Many of Duarte's earliest pioneer families came to Duarte in the mid-19th century for their health
column3: and the fertile soil. English settlers
column4: Americans from the Midwest and Deep South
column5: Latinos who remained from the Rancho and Japanese immigrants enabled Duarte to grow into a thriving agricultural community specializing in citrus production. The first recorded avocado tree grown in California was planted in Duarte by William Chappelow
column6: Sr. grown from one of four seeds sent to him by the Division of Pomology of the United States Department of Agriculture in 1893.Two medical institutions were started in Duarte in the early part of the 20th century. In 1913
column7: the Jewish Consumptive Relief Association started a tuberculosis sanitarium in the form of a small tent city on 40 acres (16 ha) of land south of Duarte Road. This later evolved into the world-renowned City of Hope National Medical Center
column8: a recognized leader in fighting cancer and other catastrophic diseases. In 1930
column9: a group of Carmelite nuns known as the Carmelite Sisters of the Most Sacred Heart of Los Angeles established what is now the Santa Teresita Rest Home
column10: known until recently as Santa Teresita Medical Center. After decades as a full-service hospital
column11: Santa Teresita was downgraded to "medical center" in the early 21st century
column13: caused both by administrative missteps as well as the costs of providing medical coverage to the uninsured
column14: forced the hospital to close its emergency room. Santa Teresita now operates as an "outpatient services only" facility.

column1: The original city logo was created by Bill Botts Sr. in 1957. It consisted of a double-circular seal
column2: with the inner circle containing an adobe arch featuring the Rancho Azusa de Duarte "d" brand (inside the arch is the original date of the Rancho's establishment
column3: 1841) while the outer circle features the year of Duarte's incorporation (1957). The current city logo was created in early 1982 to mark Duarte's 25th anniversary of cityhood.

column2: modern Duarte is a bedroom community.  The City of Duarte is geographically isolated from population centers to the east and south due to the San Gabriel River and rock quarry operations in Irwindale and Azusa. These factors have proven to be an ongoing economic challenge for local businesses as the city attracts little outside spending
column3: and most residents spend their money elsewhere. Due to air quality and noise concerns
column4: the City of Duarte has sought repeatedly to halt expansion of neighboring quarry operations
column5: but has had no success against the monied interests behind the quarries and the neighboring city governments beholden to them.  Still
column7: the city leadership has succeeded in bringing retail development to the western portion of Duarte beginning
column9: with the redevelopment of the Big Sky Drive-in Theater as a shopping plaza with a Gemco superstore (which is now a Target). Later
column12: and a well known Route-66 diner (known as the "Boulevard Cafe") were replaced with a Ralphs shopping center. In the early 21st century
column13: Walmart opened on the western edge of the city
column14: as did a CarMax used-car superstore. In 2009
column15: the city welcomed a new mini-shopping center
column17: around the site of its Staples store. As of January 2010
column18: a Sonic Drive-In opened in the Target Shopping Center. In March 2010
column19: a 99 Cents Only Store opened in the Big Lots center on Huntington. In 2016
column20: a Smart & Final Extra store replaced the Ralphs supermarket
column21: which had closed in 2015. A Grocery Outlet store replaced Mike's Foods
column22: in a heavily remodeled section of the Duarte Shopping Center at Huntington and Buena Vista.

column1: The Duarte Unified School District serves students from Duarte
column3: and unincorporated communities to the south of Duarte and Monrovia. The district contains five elementary schools (Maxwell
column4: Andres Duarte
column8: one high school (Duarte High School) and one continuation high school (Mt. Olive Continuation High School

column2: there are also five licensed private schools. Foothill Oaks Academy is a non-sectarian school serving students from preschool through 8th grade. The Duarte Montessori School is affiliated with the American Montessori Society and serves students from preschool through 2nd grade.  The School of the Little Scholar is a non-sectarian preschool. ABC School is another non-sectarian preschool that focuses on children with special education needs. The Hayden Child Care Center is a Roman Catholic-affiliated school serving students in preschool and kindergarten.
